text: Hey <@U7KKA4QQM> , they're first party. We also honor the GDPR cookie banner built into HubSpot. <https://blog.HubSpot.com/customers/apple-and-google-are-cracking-down-on-cookies.-heres-what-you-need-to-know#:~:text=HubSpot%27s%20cookies%20are%20first%2Dparty,will%20continue%20to%20contain%20data|https://blog.HubSpot.com/customers/apple-and-google-are-cracking-down-on-cookies.-heres-what-you-need-to-know#:~:text=HubSpot%27s%20cookies%20are%20first%2Dparty,will%20continue%20to%20contain%20data>.

Nice! I was worried because the cookies are stored by HubSpot and aren't domain specific how it would shake out. Sounds like it will be considered domain specific. One final question—does HubSpot aggregate the data from all cookies into one data file or are they stored separately?

Not fully sure i understand the question. A cookie is itself stored as a key value pair inside a single file in the browsers files. Websites cant influence whether the browser uses a single file to hold all cookies or separate.

There are multiple HubSpot cookies and they need to be separate as per GDPR some need to be able to be opted out of. Additionally some cookies are used for functionality like memberships, your own login to HubSpot, a/b testing.

For a comprehensive list of every possible cookie HubSpot sets and the situation they're set in see: <https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/reports/what-cookies-does-HubSpot-set-in-a-visitor-s-browser|https://knowledge.HubSpot.com/reports/what-cookies-does-HubSpot-set-in-a-visitor-s-browser>
Nice find. Wish i knew about this site years ago. I love the concept of regex but it's certainly tough to read and write.

For example, I just accepted the cookie in Chrome from our website <http://www.mediajunction.com|www.mediajunction.com> the cookie is stored as <http://HubSpot.com|HubSpot.com> on my machine…not <http://mediajunction.com|mediajunction.com>
